qas.question: What type of creativity is excluded from the US definition of IP?
What doesn't current US IP law recognize the uniqueness of?
Requiring written records enforces what kind of bias?
The Western bias is that what form is more authoritative?
Who includes common creativity in their definition of intellectual property?
What does current US IP law recognize the uniqueness of?
What bias is eliminated by asking native cultures to write down their cultural artifacts?
What definition includes any works that are result of community creativity?

context: Another limitation of current <b4_0>U.S.<b4_0/> <b7_0>Intellectual Property<b7_0/> legislation is its focus on individual and joint works; thus, copyright protection can only be obtained in 'original' works of authorship. This definition excludes any works that are the result of <a0_0>community creativity<a0_0/>, for example Native American songs and stories; current legislation does not recognize the uniqueness of <a1_0><b5_0>indigenous cultural "property"<b5_0/><a1_0/> and its ever-changing nature. Simply asking native cultures to 'write down' their cultural artifacts on tangible mediums ignores their necessary orality and enforces a <a2_0><b6_0>Western<b6_0/><a2_0/> bias of the <a3_0>written<a3_0/> form as more authoritative.
